bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Seamus Heaney was born on April 13, 1939, to Margaret and Patrick Heaney. The eldest of nine children, he was born at the family farm, Mossbawn, northwest of Belfast in County Derry. He attended the local school at Anahorish until 1957 when he enrolled at Queens College, Belfast, where he studied English. After graduation he taught English at St. Joseph's College in Belfast.

While at St. Joseph's he began to write, publishing work in university magazines under the pseudonym Incertus. During that time, he joined a poetry workshop organized by Philip Hobsbaum. In 1965, in connection with the Belfast Festival, he published Eleven Poems, and in August of that year he married Marie Devlin. The following year he became a lecturer in modern English literature at Queens College; his first son, Michael, was born; and Faber and Faber published Death of a Naturalist. This collection earned him the Eric Gregory Award, the Cholmondeley Award, the Somerset Maugham Award, and the Geoffrey Faber Memorial Prize. Marie and Seamus Heaney's second son, Christopher, was born in 1968.

Door Into the Dark, published in 1969, was a Poetry Book Society Choice for the year. In 1970-1971, Heaney was guest lecturer at the University of California, Berkeley. He returned to Northern Ireland in 1971, and in 1972 he resigned his lectureship at Queens College, moved his family to Glanmore, in County Wicklow, and published Wintering Out. In 1973 his daughter Catherine Ann was born. During this year he also received the Denis Devlin Award and the Writer in Residence Award from the American Irish Foundation. In 1975 North was published, winning the E.M. Forster Award and the Duff Cooper Memorial Prize. During these years at Glanmore, Heaney also gave many readings in the United States and England and edited two poetry anthologies.

In 1975 Heaney began teaching at Carysfort Collegein Dublin, and in 1976 he and his family moved to Sandymount in the city. In 1979 Heaney published Field Work and in 1980 Selected Poems and Preoccupations. In 1981 he gave up his position at Carysfort to become visiting professor at Harvard. In 1982 he won the Bennett Award and Queens University awarded him an honorary Doctor of Letters. He co-founded Field Day Company with the playwright Brian Friel and others in 1983. Station Island, his first collection in five years, was published in 1984. During that year he was elected Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory at Harvard. That same year his mother died.

In 1988 Seamus Heaney visited Emory University where he inaugurated the Richard Ellmann Lectures in Modern Literature. These lectures were collected and published as The Place of Writing in 1989. In 1991 Heaney published a new collection Seeing Things, followed by the Redress of Poetry in 1995. In the fall of that year, Heaney was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.

In recent years Heaney has been recipient of numerous awards and prizes. His translation of Beowulf (1999) won the Whitbread Award for best book of the year, and his Finders Keepers (2002) won the Truman Capote Award for Literary Criticism. He also has been awarded a number of honorary degrees; he is a member of Aosdana, the Irish Academy of Artist and Writers, and is a Foreign Member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters. In addition, he has been made a Comandeur de L’Ordre des Arts et Lettres by the French Ministry of Culture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Seamus Heaney papers consist of correspondence, literary manuscripts, printed material, subject files, photographs, audio-visual material, and personal papers from 1951-2004. Correspondence (1963-2004) comprises the bulk of the collection and documents Heaney’s relationship with his students, publishers, friends, and other literary figures, including Joseph Brodsky, Donald Davie, Seamus Deane, Douglas Dunn, Peter Fallon, Brian Friel, Anthony Hecht, Ted Hughes, Michael Longley, Medbh McGuckian, Paul Muldoon, and James Simmons. Literary manuscripts include a small group of poems and prose written by Heaney and many manuscripts sent to him by other literary figures and by aspiring writers. Printed material, either written by or about Seamus Heaney is present as are other printed items collected by him. Small groups of subject files, audio-visual material, and personal papers are included as well as a large group of photographs from 1951-2003.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into eight series: (1) Correspondence, (2) Writings by others, (3) Printed material, (4) Subject files, (5) Photographs, (6) Audio-visual material, (7) Personal papers, and (8) Writings by Seamus Heaney.

separatedmaterial.head: Related Materials in This Repository
separatedmaterial.p: Ciaran Carson papers, Peter Fallon-The Gallery Press collection, Ted Hughes papers, Michael Longley papers, Derek Mahon papers, Medbh McGuckian papers, Seamus Heaney collection, Charles Monteith collection, Paul Muldoon papers, Frank Ormsby papers, Tom Paulin papers, Ron Schuchard papers, and James Simmons papers.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, 1963-2004

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence series contains general correspondence, literary correspondence, outgoing correspondence, and other correspondence from 1963-2004. The extensive collection of correspondence is arranged chronologically with the bulk falling between 1978 and 2002. Many of the letters relate to speaking and reading engagements, queries from aspiring writers, requests for recommendations, and letters from admirers of Heaney's work. Also present in the collection is an important group of letters from his friends and literary associates (1964-2003), notably John Banville, Joseph Brodsky, Seamus Deane, Douglas Dunn, Peter Fallon, Tom Flanagan, Brian Friel, Philip Hobsbaum, Ted Hughes, Brendan Kennelly, Thomas Kilroy, Michael Longley, Medbh McGuckian, Derek Mahon, John Montague, Paul Muldoon, Bernard O'Donoghue, Tom Paulin, and Derek Walcott. A small amount of literary correspondence from these and other individuals accompany writings and is found attached to those writings in the Writings by Others series.

Included in this series is a large group of outgoing letters (1967-2003), in the original holograph or typescript and signed by Heaney, which were sent by telefacsimile. There are also invitations, letters of recommendation, and letters from many of Heaney's publishers. The series documents Heaney's writing career as well as his relationships with many students, literary colleagues, and friends.

accessrestrict.p: Special restrictions apply: Series 1, Correspondence, is closed to researchers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: (1.1) General correspondence, (1.2) Literary correspondence, (1.3) Outgoing correspondence, and (1.4) Other correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series includes a large number of writings about Seamus Heaney as well as writings about a variety of other subjects from 1964-2004. The majority of the writings about Heaney consist of reviews and translations of his work, essays, and poems about him. Other writings include poems, reviews, scripts, translations, essays and other prose. These manuscripts, which may be photocopies, original holographs, or typescripts, often have accompanying letters. The writings are arranged in alphabetical order by author, and include writings by Joseph Brodsky, Patrick Crotty, Donald Davie, Seamus Deane, Ted Hughes, Patrick Kavanagh, Michael Longley, Medbh McGuckian, Derek Mahon, Paul Muldoon, and James Simmons. Of particular interest is a collection of poems written by Ted Hughes, the majority of which are included in Birthday Letters, and a large number of early poems by Michael Longley, some of which are holograph manuscripts signed by Longley.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: (2.1) Writings about Seamus Heaney and (2.2) Other writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The printed materials consist of writings by Seamus Heaney, writings about him, reviews of his writings, and miscellaneous collected printed materials from 1958-2003. Writings by Heaney (1965-2003) include poems printed and reprinted in periodical literature, essays written by Heaney, reviews of other authors' writings, proofs of work being published, and translations done by Heaney. Writings about Heaney (1966-2002) include news articles; promotional materials for his writings, readings, and lectures; and cartoons, catalogs, postcards, and programs which relate to Heaney. The series also contains many printed reviews of Heaney's writings which appeared in newspapers and literary publications from 1966-2002. These reviews are primarily in the form of clippings.

Also present in the series are printed materials collected by Seamus Heaney from 1958-2003. These collected materials consist of writings by others, including Alfred Alcorn, Gerald Dawes, Dana Gioia, John Montague, Hayden Murphy, and Connor Cruise O'Brien; as well as miscellaneous programs, broadsides, pamphlets and leaflets.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: (3.1) Writings by Seamus Heaney, (3.2) Writings about Seamus Heaney, (3.3) Reviews and (3.4) Collected printed materials.

did.unittitle: Writings by Seamus Heaney, 1965-2003

scopecontent.head: Scope and content note
scopecontent.p: The subseries consists of a variety of Heaney's writings printed in programs, newspapers, literary journals, cards and book jackets from 1965-2003.

Writings about Seamus Heaney, 1965-2004

scopecontent.head: Scope and content note
scopecontent.p: Writings about Seamus Heaney consist of articles and essays published by others including Seamus Deane, Terrance Des Pres, Theo Dorgan, Darcy O'Brien, and Bernard O'Donoghue from 1965-2002. Also included are clippings taken from periodical literature (1965-2002); flyers, leaflets and posters publicizing Heaney readings, writings and lectures; and a variety of cartoons, catalogs, post cards and programs, all of which relate to Heaney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and content note
scopecontent.p: The collected printed materials consist of a variety of materials collected by Seamus Heaney from 1958-2003, including poems, essays, chapbooks, galley proofs, and offprints of other writers. Also present are a small collection of periodicals and a larger group of programs collected by Heaney.

Photographs, 1951-2003

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of photographs dating from 1951-2003 and include both amateur snapshots and professionally produced images, some in color and others in black and white. There are photographs of Seamus Heaney, photographs of Heaney with other individuals, other individuals and groups, objects, places, and other miscellaneous photographs from 1951-2003. The photographs of Heaney include portraits in academic regalia, publicity photographs, and a small number by Rollie McKeena. The snapshots were sent to Heaney primarily by acquaintances. The photographs of Heaney with other individuals (1958-2003) comprise the largest group and include many colleagues and friends, notably Derek Mahon, Michael Longley, Ted Hughes, Paul Muldoon, Brian Friel, Seamus Deane, Derek Walcott, Philip Hobsbaum and Joseph Brodsky. Many are snapshots, and a small number include family members. The series also includes a group of photographs of other individuals and a small number of photographs of objects and places.

Audio-Visual materials, 1994-2002

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of a small number of audiocassettes, videocassettes, and compact discs from 1994-2002. These are primarily recordings of public appearances and readings by Heaney. Also included are miscellaneous recordings related to poetry which were sent to Heaney by acquaintances.

did.unittitle: Audiocassettes
"Goosebumps and Tingles," presenter: Seamus Caulfield, compiler: Sheila O'Callaghan, recorded from Ireland RTE Radio 1, includes a reading by Seamus Heaney of his poem, "Belderg," undated
William Butler Yeats reading his own poetry, recorded from unknown source, sent to Seamus Heaney by Peter O'Shaughnessy, undated
Seamus Heaney reading at the University of Melbourne (Australia), October 1994

"Seamus Heaney at Melbourne Writer's Festival, side one: "Evening with Edna O'Brien," and discussion of religious poetry: "God Moves in Mysterious Metres," side two: continuation of side one discussion and "Poems Read on BBC Television broadcast presented by Melvyn Bragg, includes Seamus Heaney reading his poetry, 1994 [digitized: Emory:b7rdr, b7rfw]

"The Open Mind," BBC Radio, celebrating the achievement of Seamus Heaney in his winning the Nobel Prize for Literature. Includes broadcast of Heaney's opening address ["Words Alone"] to the World Congress of the International Reading Association (Dublin), 27 July 1982, taped from radio broadcast, 1995

"The Box Seat," second in the International Voices Poetry series, presented by David Britton, Australian Broadcasting Company, features Seamus Heaney, reading his poetry. Recorded at the 1994 Melbourne Writers Festival, broadcast ca. 1995
Meridian Radio documentary on Joseph Brodsky from the series Meridian Features, presenter: Elizabeth Robson; producer: Jenny Hargreaves; included is a statement read by Seamus Heaney, February 1996
Mediumwave, RTE Radio program regarding Irish journalism, includes Seamus Heaney on the art of poetry and journalism, 1 July 1996
Seeing Things," text by Seamus Heaney and music by Dario Marianelli [for the Rotterdamse Dansegroep], August 1996

"Farewell to Stromness," produced by Elizabeth Clark, music by Sir Peter Maxwell Davie. Six poets read their own specially commissioned tributes to George Mackay Brown who died in April 1996. Poets included are Seamus Heaney, Iain Crichton Smith, Liz Lochead, Stewart Conn, Edwina Morgan and Kenneth White, ca. 1997

"Viewing the Century," Les Murray talks with Kevin Jackson about rationalism and the dream world, Australian writing and universities, and atrocity in the twentieth century, BBC Radio 3 interview, 13 September 1998
Yeats Poetry, read by Peter O'Shaughnessy, undated

Writings by Seamus Heaney, 1966-2004

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The writings of Seamus Heaney consist of works of poetry, translation, and prose from the early 1960's-2004. Included in the group of poetry and translation are holograph poems, some typescript poems with extensive revision and a few untitled poems and fragments. Most are undated and all have been arranged alphabetically. The works of prose include addresses and lectures, British Broadcasting Corporation scripts, eulogies, notes, other prose, and editing projects. The majority of the prose works are dated and all have been arranged chronologically. Early prose consists of a small number of graded essays written by Heaney as a student. Most notable of the editing projects in the series is one shared with Ted Hughes, The School Bag, which includes lists of poems, correspondence, and files of photocopied items under consideration for the anthology.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: (8.1) Poetry and translations and (8.2) Prose.

did.unittitle: Poetry and translations, 1969-2003

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Arranged by record type, then in alphabetical order.
